title: Jack: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss: A Work-Related Investigation
chief_complaint: I have been having trouble communicating for the past several years, especially in noisy places like meetings or on the phone. I noticed my hearing getting worse gradually. At work, I had to make a choice, my ears or my eyes, and I chose my eyes.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual onset over approximately 32 years of employment.
problem_summary.course: Progressive decline, documented by sporadic workplace monitoring since 1971.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral mild tinnitus described as 'annoying in quiet'.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty understanding speech in noise, meetings, and on the telephone. Family complains about hearing ability at home and socially.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking workers' compensation determination and assistance with communication.

history.present_illness: 58-year-old male evaluated for workers' compensation claim. Reports gradual bilateral hearing loss and mild tinnitus. Denies fluctuation, drainage, or vertigo.
history.otologic_history: Negative for ear pain, drainage, fullness, or surgeries. History of childhood mumps and measles.
history.noise_exposure_history: USAF (1967-69) jet engine exposure. Manufacturing/Construction (1971-2003) involving jackhammers, grinders, and welding. Intermittent HPD use; often prioritized face shields over earmuffs due to incompatibility. Recreational exposure to firearms (hunting) and power tools.
history.medical_psych_history: Smoker (30 years). Negative for diabetes, kidney disease, or head injury.
history.prior_management: Sporadic workplace screenings (1971, 1979, 1984) showed progressive loss but no intervention was taken. Never wore hearing aids.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral normal hearing in the low frequencies sloping to severe high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. A 'noise notch' configuration is evident, though eroding into a slope due to age/progression. Significant threshold shift (STS) confirmed compared to 1971 baseline.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech reception thresholds consistent with pure tone averages. Word recognition scores are good bilaterally at elevated presentation levels.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present at expected sensation levels for 500-2000 Hz; absent at 4000 Hz consistent with hearing loss.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAE)
tests.key_findings: Consistent with cochlear pathology in high frequencies.

tests.name: Hearing Protection Fit Check
tests.key_findings: Sound field thresholds measured with and without foam earplugs (NRR 33). Visual inspection showed good insertion. Attenuation was adequate.

history.present_illness: Referral for medical evaluation of progressive SNHL and determination of work-relatedness.
history.medical_psych_history: History of surgeries (hand, shoulder, stomach). Smoker's pharyngitis noted.

tests.name: Physical Exam and Labs
tests.key_findings: Normal otoscopy. Labs (CBC, sedrate, TSH, T4, FTA-ABS) normal, ruling out systemic causes. Diagnosis: Bilateral SNHL secondary to noise exposure (95% attributed to workplace).

history.present_illness: Hearing aid fitting following workers' compensation settlement.
history.patient_goals: Improve communication with granddaughter and in meetings.

tests.name: Hearing Aid Fitting
tests.key_findings: Binaural programmable hearing aids dispensed. Patient reported excellent subjective benefit and full-time use, though he removes them to use earplugs at work.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetric, sensorineural hearing loss that is normal in the low frequencies and slopes precipitously to a severe degree in the high frequencies. The configuration shows a characteristic 'noise notch' pattern that has widened over time, consistent with long-term noise exposure. Speech recognition is good in quiet but likely significantly degraded in noise due to the loss of high-frequency cues. There is no evidence of retrocochlear pathology or functional hearing loss.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is permanent and directly related to the loud noise exposure over your career.
It is critical that you continue to wear hearing protection at work and when shooting firearms to prevent further damage.
Hearing aids will help you hear high-pitched sounds like speech consonants, making it easier to understand conversations, especially with your granddaughter.
While hearing aids improve audibility, they do not restore normal hearing; you may still face challenges in very noisy environments.
We will schedule annual hearing tests to monitor for any further changes.
notes_for_actor: You are a hardworking, blue-collar maintenance man. You are not looking for a 'free ride' but you want the company to acknowledge the safety gaps.
When discussing the lack of earplugs, express frustration but resignation: you had to wear a face shield for safety, and the earmuffs didn't fit with it, so you chose to protect your eyes.
You are cooperative with testing and honest about your hunting history.
You are motivated to hear your family better, specifically your granddaughter.
